EAA06C36E06E40EA95C47944AC8E3088.description: Teacher believes that discipline does not equal punishment but, rather, is about learning and growth.

172F4CFE504D4926AA672068D768D89D.description: Teacher embraces the core beliefs of the NCP. Teacher collaborates with restorative coaches.

725E8E8F30F640FD91A609A0E5CFD0C7.description: Reflection: Teachers recognize and continuously reflect upon how personal culture, mindsets, biases, and privileges impact their teaching and their classroom.

4C6C24082F05463A880A5D1646A4986D.description: Learning: Teachers are always seeking to learn more about oppressive histories, systems, and structures.

FDF7383BEEB74416A6744758A65FD564.description: Diverse Learners: Teacher regularly collaborates with campus and community experts to serve diverse learners most effectively.

A6AFBCF4BE8F498180E0C0484181C8FC.description: High Expectations: Teacher believes that all students can grow, learn, and achieve. Teacher consistently disrupts deficit-based thinking.

AC60C04E74BF4C35B501990C140DCB14.description:
Teacher Beliefs:
These mindsets undergird the ability to fully actualize an Anti-racist Noble Classroom

9D49893CB3184406A53E2D17FB3FB961.description: Teacher has made classroom community norms visible. (SS, E)

6BE33F882DDB4C1E9D44114E9EF01D50.description: Language: home, youth, and cultural language is welcomed and used. (SS, CRST)

970AA8BFC41743B1AEA5B88C14A1F045.description: Criticality: Teacher counteracts dominant narratives and structures by creating opportunities for student agency, and critique. (CRST, E)

5E7F48CC3F9646CBBA513EFEF8DD39B9.description: Teacher models self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, and responsible decision-making. (SS)

C20C4C8362D740ED95C50B487F67C139.description:
Incorporate Google Classroom engagement into classroom norms. This includes posting and maintaining a 
class syllabus, assignments, relevant calendars/learning sequences for reference so students, families and 
school staff can access anytime and anywhere to stay informed. (IT, E)

F5834CE85599448195EE21023FE55A19.description: Teacher routinely integrates classroom community norms into the lesson.

4151824D5BAD47DC947CAFF5A07F6C8E.description:
The Noble Community Pact:
Students have internalized classroom routines and structures and uphold them as members of the community. Student needs are identified and addressed effectively so that learning continues and a sense of belonging in the community is maintained.

1A48F127C6FA4B04817FB12E29A98257.description: Identity: Teacher makes continuous efforts to get to know students, their intersecting identities, cultures, experiences, and strengths. Teachers affirm, in multiple ways, student identity and strengths. (SS, I, CRST)

DD5D84EEE5984FD0928B73692355EC0A.description: Teachers affirm, in multiple ways, student identity and strengths. (SS, I, CRST)

9BD404BD01BB4E4C8BD57BC5FBF52055.description: Teacher inquires (asks "why") before responding to potential breaches of the community pact. (SS)

2DA3CA264284485486D32CB9EB91FCFC.description: Teacher responds to breaches in classroom expectations in a way that addresses the cause, protects the classroom community, is aligned with CRST, and models the desired behavior. (SS)

776AF146113E446CB66C49A272621B49.description: Relevance: Teacher focuses learning experiences around a problem or question that connects their content to students, their lives, and/or the sociopolitical context. (CRST)

C523802FAE8242AC97324DD8C88FE7E5.description:
CRST:
The classroom is centered on students. Students are joyful. They are safe to be themselves, make mistakes, ask questions, and engage in discussion. They can articulate what they are learning and how it relates to their current life, world, or reality. They can see themselves in the learning and are building an academic identity. Students provide feedback on the classroom experience that results in adjustments to the classroom. Students provide critique and engage in authentic dialogue.
"

3762298915124B9D81E110BAAFF0E3B6.description: Content & Skills: Teacher provides high-quality texts, problems, and tasks to support the most important standards and skills within the grade-level/content area. Skills not yet demonstrated are spiraled into grade-level units rather than taught in isolation as remediation. (SD, IT, CL, CRST)

07045533E61B40669AC9E86151FBBECD.description: Relating: Teacher provides an explicit "entry point" for students to make sense of the work (connects to previous work, prior knowledge, or familiar reference). (CL, I, IT, CRST)

50D3E866C3CC438D9A583166576213F9.description: Relating: Teacher uses media and technology purposefully to connect to students.  (CL, I, IT, CRST)

B27F295139864F4A9CC54C5518296D4F.description: Making Meaning: Teacher provides opportunities for students to incorporate new knowledge into existing schema; students can answer the "so what" question. (CL, CRST)

19F6F81D48F64674B0622AA58DFCDF5F.description: Checks for Understanding: Teacher uses formative checks for understanding throughout the lesson (not always or only at the end); timely, high-leverage feedback is provided. Teacher provides and models thinking routines for making sense of assignments, for when you get stuck, and for specific content and tasks.  (SD, IT, CL, QR)

6933A46B013F458D9E3A801F22FD6D7C.description: Rigor: Teachers require complex and critical thinking in order to demonstrate understanding; scaffolds, accommodations, and choice are provided so that all students can demonstrate understanding. Teacher offers multiple "retakes" and enables students to demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways. (SD, IT, CL, E)

8AE8EFA063EF4BC3A36E9116CCE01B93.description: Self-Assessment & Reflection: Teacher provides consistent opportunities for students to self-assess against success criteria and goals, reflect on their learning, and provide feedback regarding how they are learning. (QR, E)

FC302FC4AF2F4C62BD86451282BDFC8F.description:
"Learning Acceleration:
Students successfully learn grade-level and developmentally appropriate content and skills. Students refine their thinking based on feedback from teachers and peers. Students can often get themselves ""unstuck"" and demonstrate metacognitive strategies. Students are able to demonstrate their understanding in various ways and at various times."
